source.d591b9c5:
data1 = pd.read_csv("../input/student-alcohol-consumption/student-mat.csv",sep=",")
data2 = pd.read_csv("../input/student-alcohol-consumption/student-por.csv",sep=",")
data = [data1,data2]
data=pd.concat(data)
data=shuffle(data)
data.describe(include="all")

data = data.dropna()

data.describe(include="all")

source.a843d3a3:
#data cleaning(binary and onehot encodings)
datagrade.school[datagrade.school == 'GP'] = 1
datagrade.school[datagrade.school == 'MS'] = 0
datagrade.sex[datagrade.sex == 'M'] = 1
datagrade.sex[datagrade.sex == 'F'] = 0
datagrade.address[datagrade.address == 'U'] = 1
datagrade.address[datagrade.address == 'R'] = 0
datagrade.famsize[datagrade.famsize == 'GT3'] = 1
datagrade.famsize[datagrade.famsize == 'LE3'] = 0
datagrade.Pstatus[datagrade.Pstatus == 'T'] = 1
datagrade.Pstatus[datagrade.Pstatus == 'A'] = 0
#for Medu & Fedu its better in numeric as higher education has higher difference with primary than secondary
#one hot encoding of necessary features
cols_to_transform = [ 'Mjob','Fjob','reason','guardian' ]
datagrade=pd.get_dummies(datagrade,columns=cols_to_transform) 
#failures, traveltime, studytime does not require onehot

datagrade.famsup[datagrade.famsup == 'no'] = 0

datagrade.paid[datagrade.paid == 'no'] = 0

datagrade.activities[datagrade.activities == 'no'] = 0

datagrade.romantic[datagrade.romantic == 'no'] = 0

source.0831034a:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier 
from sklearn.metrics import confusion_matrix 
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, r2_score
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score, f1_score, precision_score, recall_score, classification_report, confusion_matrix
from sklearn.tree import export_graphviz
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import cv2


dtree_model = DecisionTreeClassifier(max_depth = 2).fit(X_grade_train, y_grade_train) 
dtree_predictions = dtree_model.predict(X_grade_test) 
export_graphviz(dtree_model, 'tree.dot', feature_names = FEATURE_GRADE)  
! dot -Tpng tree.dot -o tree.png
%matplotlib inline
img = cv2.imread('tree.png')
plt.figure(figsize = (20, 20))
plt.imshow(img)
acc = f1_score(y_grade_test, dtree_predictions, average="macro")
print("F1 score for Predicting final grade using decision tree of max 2 depth: " + str(acc))

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier 
from sklearn.metrics import confusion_matrix 
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, r2_score
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score, f1_score, precision_score, recall_score, classification_report, confusion_matrix




dtree_model = DecisionTreeClassifier(max_depth = 10).fit(X_grade_train, y_grade_train) 
dtree_predictions = dtree_model.predict(X_grade_test) 
export_graphviz(dtree_model, 'tree.dot', feature_names = FEATURE_GRADE)  
! dot -Tpng tree.dot -o tree.png
%matplotlib inline
img = cv2.imread('tree.png')
plt.figure(figsize = (20, 20))
plt.imshow(img)    
acc = f1_score(y_grade_test, dtree_predictions, average="macro")
print("F1 score for Predicting final grade using decision tree of max 10 depth: " + str(acc))

source.f2a50d62:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier 
from sklearn.metrics import confusion_matrix 
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, r2_score
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score, f1_score, precision_score, recall_score, classification_report, confusion_matrix




dtree_model = DecisionTreeClassifier(max_depth = 50).fit(X_grade_train, y_grade_train) 
dtree_predictions = dtree_model.predict(X_grade_test) 
export_graphviz(dtree_model, 'tree.dot', feature_names = FEATURE_GRADE)  
! dot -Tpng tree.dot -o tree.png
%matplotlib inline
img = cv2.imread('tree.png')
plt.figure(figsize = (20, 20))
plt.imshow(img)    
acc = f1_score(y_grade_test, dtree_predictions, average="macro")
print("F1 score for Predicting final grade using decision tree of max 50 depth: " + str(acc))

source.3b46b53b:
from sklearn.neighbors import KNeighborsClassifier 

knn = KNeighborsClassifier(n_neighbors = 7).fit(X_grade_train, y_grade_train) 
knn_predictions = knn.predict(X_grade_test) 

acc = f1_score(y_grade_test, knn_predictions, average="macro")
print("F1 score for Predicting final grade using KNN classifier: " + str(acc))



knn = KNeighborsClassifier(n_neighbors = 7).fit(X_alc_weekday_train, y_alc_weekday_train) 
knn_predictions = knn.predict(X_alc_weekday_test) 
  
acc = f1_score(y_alc_weekday_test, knn_predictions, average="macro")
print("F1 score for Predicting alchohol consumption in weekdays using KNN classifier: " + str(acc))



knn = KNeighborsClassifier(n_neighbors = 7).fit(X_alc_weekend_train, y_alc_weekend_train) 
knn_predictions = knn.predict(X_alc_weekend_test) 
  
acc = f1_score(y_alc_weekend_test, knn_predictions, average="macro")
print("F1 score for Predicting alchohol consumption in weekends using KNN classifier: " + str(acc))
source.e7e1ae95:
from sklearn.naive_bayes import GaussianNB



gnb = GaussianNB().fit(X_grade_train, y_grade_train) 
gnb_predictions = gnb.predict(X_grade_test) 

acc = f1_score(y_grade_test, gnb_predictions, average="macro")
print("F1 score for Predicting final grade using Naive Bayes Classifier: " + str(acc))


gnb = GaussianNB().fit(X_alc_weekday_train, y_alc_weekday_train) 
gnb_predictions = gnb.predict(X_alc_weekday_test) 
  
acc = f1_score(y_alc_weekday_test, gnb_predictions, average="macro")
print("F1 score for Predicting alchohol consumption in weekdays using Naive Bayes Classifier: " + str(acc))


gnb = GaussianNB().fit(X_alc_weekend_train, y_alc_weekend_train) 
gnb_predictions = gnb.predict(X_alc_weekend_test) 
  
acc = f1_score(y_alc_weekend_test, gnb_predictions, average="macro")
print("F1 score for Predicting alchohol consumption in weekends using Naive Bayes Classifier: " + str(acc))
source.d6b4c65f: It is clear that number of female students are more than number of male students in both the  schools, with 'GP' - Gabriel Pereira school having more number of students overall.
source.1c5bf8aa: So from here we can conclude, that there were no tuples with NULL or infinite values.
source.cd628ea0: It seems very large amount of people drink very low alcohol(1) during both weekend and work days. Most of the people who drink high(4,5) are male and also people who drink high during work days are getting bit lower grades than that of others.
source.5f1591e1:
**Statements based on heatmap values**
We can observe few good  correlation values between health and alcohol consumption also alcohol consumption with failures. And also as expected study time has a good correlation value with grades and father edu, mother edu and failures also have good correlation values with grades and first period and second period grades matter a lot to the final grade(high corrleation values). Surprisingly absences and health have low correlation values with the grades.
source.c7139907: It seems females have a higher chance of being in a relationship than male students.
source.83f0745b: It seems most of the urban people are having internet availability and also performing better than rural people.
source.4044ffd9: Removing duplicates leads to 662 tuples, which implies there were 382 duplicate tuples in the two datasets
